questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency department for pain and swelling of his left knee one day after injuring it while playing soccer. While sprinting on the field, he slipped as he attempted to kick the ball and landed on the anterior aspect of his knee. He underwent an appendectomy at the age of 16 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The tibial tuberosity shows tenderness to palpation. The left tibia is displaced posteriorly when force is applied to the proximal tibia after flexing the knee. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the left knee joint shows an avulsion fracture of the tibial condyle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury manifests with knee pain, but it would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. Instead, ACL injury would manifest with a positive anterior drawer sign and a positive Lachman sign.

B) INCORRECT:

Lateral meniscus injury would manifest with knee pain, but it would not explain this patient's positive posterior drawer test and his avulsion fracture. Meniscus injury may be differentiated from ligamentous injuries by considering the mechanism of injury (axial loading in meniscal injury vs. valgus or varus stresses in ligamentous injury), effusion course (slow, gradual, and delayed in meniscal injury vs. rapid in ligamentous injury), and presence of popping/clicking/locking (present in meniscal injury vs. absent in ligamentous injury).

C) CORRECT:

Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injuries are either noncontact injuries involving hyperflexion of the knee on a plantarflexed foot (most commonly seen in athletes) or injuries caused by a posterior blow to the flexed knee (e.g., dashboard injury, athletic contact injury). A positive posterior drawer sign is highly suggestive of PCL injury, and the diagnosis can be confirmed by MRI. Avulsion fractures are common in PCL injury. Isolated PCL injury can be treated conservatively; multiligament injuries and/or chronic symptoms typically warrant surgery.

Patients with PCL injury sometimes appear to have a positive anterior drawer sign because the affected knee seems to have significantly more anterior movement compared to the unaffected knee (due to starting from a posteriorly displaced position).
Image Description:

MRI knee (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) appears thickened and heterogeneous with an irregular and ill-defined contour (green overlay). It contains multiple areas of intermediate signal intensity, indicating tearing. A joint effusion is demonstrated by the hyperintense signal in the suprapatellar pouch (red overlay).

A ligament tear does not always appear as a discrete defect and may be demonstrated by the features in this example. A normal PCL should appear as hypointense on all conventional MRI sequences and have smooth margins.

D) INCORRECT:

Lateral collateral ligament (LCL) injury can cause knee pain. However, it would not explain the patient's positive posterior drawer test or tibial avulsion fracture. Isolated LCL injury is rare and manifests with lateral joint line tenderness with varus stress laxity.

E) INCORRECT:

Medial meniscus injury is a common cause of knee pain. However, a torn medial meniscus would not explain this patient's positive posterior drawer test or avulsion fracture. Meniscus injury may be differentiated from ligamentous injuries by considering the mechanism of injury (axial loading in meniscal injury vs. valgus or varus stresses in ligamentous injury), effusion course (slow, gradual, and delayed in meniscal injury vs. rapid in ligamentous injury), and presence of popping/clicking/locking (present in meniscal injury vs. absent in ligamentous injury).

F) INCORRECT:

Medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury can manifest with knee pain. However, it would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. MCL injury is most commonly caused by valgus stress and manifests with medial joint line tenderness and valgus stress laxity.
questions.hint: Further examination would likely show the tibia of the injured leg sagging posteriorly compared to the right side when both knees are flexed (posterior sag sign).

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her coach 30 minutes after injuring her left knee while playing field hockey. She was tackled from the left side and has been unable to bear weight on her left leg since the accident. She fears the left knee may be unstable upon standing. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The medial joint line is tender to touch. The patient's hip is slightly flexed and abducted, and the knee is slightly flexed while the patient is in the supine position. Gentle valgus stress is applied across the left knee and medial joint laxity is noted. The remainder of the examination shows no further abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with posterior cruciate ligament injury often present with knee swelling. However, physical examination usually shows posterior knee instability rather than medial instability, and affected individuals usually experience minimal or no pain. In addition, injury caused by lateral direct force to the knee is an uncommon cause of posterior cruciate ligament injury, which is most commonly caused by noncontact injuries involving hyperflexion of the knee with a plantarflexed foot or contact injuries with force applied from the posterior side of the knee.
Image Description:

MRI knee (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) appears thickened and heterogeneous with an irregular and ill-defined contour (green overlay). It contains multiple areas of intermediate signal intensity, indicating tearing. A joint effusion is demonstrated by the hyperintense signal in the suprapatellar pouch (red overlay).

A ligament tear does not always appear as a discrete defect and may be demonstrated by the features in this example. A normal PCL should appear as hypointense on all conventional MRI sequences and have smooth margins.

B) INCORRECT:

Knee swelling and medial knee pain may be caused by medial meniscus injury. However, meniscus tears do not usually cause knee instability. Moreover, a lesion of the medial meniscus would typically lead to pain during adduction of the knee (varus stress), not during abduction (valgus stress), making the diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

MRI knee (upper image: T1-weighted, coronal plane; lower image: T1-weighted, sagittal plane)

There is horizontal linear intermediate signal (white outline), parallel to the tibial plateau, within the posterior horn of the medial meniscus (green overlay).

This is consistent with a horizontal meniscal tear.

Red overlay: anterior horn of the medial meniscus

C) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury include knee swelling, pain, and instability after an inciting trauma. However, ACL injury most frequently occurs in the setting of noncontact sports injuries with a twisting mechanism, not a direct blow to the knee. In addition, valgus stress test would show anterior knee instability, not medial knee instability.
Image Description:

MRI knee (STIR; sagittal view)

The anterior cruciate ligament is discontinuous. The distal part of the ligament demonstrates normal hypointense signal (red overlay), but the proximal half ligament demonstrates heterogenous hyperintense signal (yellow overlay). There is a gap between these two areas. There is also a large suprapatellar joint effusion (demonstrated as a white area due to high signal intensity; blue overlay). The partially imaged posterior cruciate ligament (green overlay) appears intact.

This is an example of an anterior cruciate ligament rupture. The gap between the proximal and distal half of the ligament indicates it is a full-thickness tear. The heterogeneous hyperintense signal of the proximal half indicates partial thickness tearing of that component.

D) INCORRECT:

Lateral collateral ligament (LCL) injury typically manifests with knee swelling, pain, and instability. However, affected individuals typically have a positive varus stress test, not a positive valgus stress test. LCL injury is typically caused by varus stress with possible external rotation, not a lateral force to the knee (valgus stress).

E) CORRECT:

This patient has the characteristic features of medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury, including medial joint line tenderness and medial joint laxity, as confirmed by a positive valgus stress test. Knee swelling and pain are also commonly seen in this condition. Contact injury involving valgus stress on the knee, such as a tackle from the side, is the mechanism that most commonly causes MCL injury.

MCL injury is frequently associated with a medial meniscus tear, which can be assessed on physical exam. In this case, the remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities, which makes a concurrent meniscus injury less likely.
Image Description:

A triad of medial meniscus, anterior cruciate ligament, and medial collateral ligament tears. This injury typically occurs due to excessive valgus and external rotational stress with a fixed foot position.

F) INCORRECT:

Individuals with lateral meniscus injury may present with knee swelling and tenderness as well as pain in the joint line when applying valgus stress to the affected knee. However, the pain is located in the lateral, not the medial joint line, making the diagnosis unlikely in this patient. In addition, isolated meniscus tears are usually not associated with knee instability.
questions.hint: The patient's injury is likely to be one of the injuries that comprise the unhappy triad.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe knee pain and swelling that began 30 minutes earlier while she was at soccer practice. She was running down the field, suddenly “cut inwards”, and heard a loud pop when she first felt the pain. She is unable to bear weight on the right knee. Examination shows marked edema and tenderness to palpation of the anterior right knee. When the knee is flexed and anterior traction is provided to the foreleg, anterior translation of the foreleg is observed. An illustration of a normal right knee in anterior view is shown. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is injury to which of the following labeled structures?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

“A” refers to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), the most commonly injured knee ligament. The mechanism of this patient's injury is typical for damage to the ACL: Sudden deceleration and twisting to change direction as occurs during pivoting movements (e.g., “cutting inwards”). This results in an audible pop followed by knee swelling (i.e., hemarthrosis) and joint instability. Clinical tests for injury to the ACL (e.g., the Lachman test, anterior drawer test, and pivot shift test) assess for laxity of the injured ligament compared to the contralateral side.

The ACL can be injured in isolation or together with other structures in the knee joint (e.g., along with the medial meniscus, as part of the “unhappy triad”).
Image Description:

Left: The menisci are anchored centrally in the intercondylar area (orange). The attachment points of the anterior (green) and posterior (blue) cruciate ligaments are also marked.

Right: The attachment points of the cruciate ligaments are marked.

B) INCORRECT:

“B” refers to the lateral meniscus, which can be injured when sudden directional change is applied to a flexed knee with the foot firmly planted, similar to the pivoting movement described by this patient. Examination of a patient with a tear of the lateral meniscus would show a positive McMurray test and a positive Apley grinding test on internal rotation of the leg. However, the positive Lachman test described here indicates injury of another structure.

C) INCORRECT:

“C” refers to the lateral collateral ligament (LCL), which is not commonly injured in isolation. The typical mechanism for injury to the LCL is force applied to a fully extended knee from the medial or anteromedial aspect of the joint (varus stress), which is not the scenario described here. Clinical signs of injury to the LCL are a positive varus stress test and lateral joint laxity. The positive Lachman test described here, however, indicates injury of another structure.

D) INCORRECT:

“D” refers to the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL), which is most commonly injured when a flexed knee receives a sudden posterior-directed force (e.g., the dashboard injury). It can also be injured in sports during a fall onto a flexed knee with a plantarflexed foot, which is not the scenario described in this case. The clinical sign of injury to the PCL is posterior movement with traction (i.e., a positive posterior drawer test). However, the Lachman test described here indicates injury of another structure.

E) INCORRECT:

“E” refers to the medial meniscus, which can be injured when sudden directional change is applied to a flexed knee with the foot firmly planted, similar to the pivoting movement described by this patient. Examination of a patient with a tear of the medial meniscus would show a positive McMurray test and a positive Apley grinding test on external rotation of the leg. However, the positive Lachman test described here indicates injury of another structure.

F) INCORRECT:

“F” refers to the medial collateral ligament (MCL), which can be injured when sudden directional change is applied to a flexed knee with the foot firmly planted, similar to the pivoting movement described by this patient. It can also be damaged by a direct blow to the lateral knee (valgus stress). Clinical signs of injury to the MCL are a positive valgus stress test and medial joint laxity, but the positive Lachman test described here indicates injury of another structure.
questions.hint: The test performed here is the Lachman test. In this case, it is positive, demonstrating laxity.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of pain and swelling in his right knee that began 3 days ago when he fell during football practice. He fell on his flexed right knee as he dove to complete a pass. He felt some mild knee pain but continued to practice. Over the next 2 days, the pain worsened and the knee began to swell. Today, the patient has an antalgic gait. Examination shows a swollen and tender right knee; flexion is limited by pain. The right knee is flexed and pressure is applied to proximal tibia; 8 mm of backward translation of the foreleg is observed. Which of the following is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medial meniscus injury is a common cause of knee pain but would not explain this patient's positive posterior drawer test. Instead, McMurray test would be positive.

B) CORRECT:

Posterior cruciate ligament injury (PCL injury) can occur when the flexed knee is subjected to excessive posterior force, as in the case of this patient. He has a positive posterior drawer sign on the affected side, which is highly suggestive of PCL injury. PCL injury is confirmed by MRI and can be treated conservatively (in the case of isolated injury) or surgically (in the case of multi-ligament injury or chronic symptoms).
Image Description:

MRI knee (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) appears thickened and heterogeneous with an irregular and ill-defined contour (green overlay). It contains multiple areas of intermediate signal intensity, indicating tearing. A joint effusion is demonstrated by the hyperintense signal in the suprapatellar pouch (red overlay).

A ligament tear does not always appear as a discrete defect and may be demonstrated by the features in this example. A normal PCL should appear as hypointense on all conventional MRI sequences and have smooth margins.

C) INCORRECT:

Anterior cruciate ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. Instead, ACL injury would present with a positive anterior drawer sign and a positive Lachman sign.

Patients with PCL injury can sometimes appear to have a positive anterior drawer sign if the examiner is not careful. If a patient has a posterior sag sign from their PCL injury, then the affected tibia is posteriorly displaced when the knee is flexed (as when performing an anterior drawer test). If the examiner is not aware of the posterior sag and performs an anterior drawer test, the affected knee will feel as though it has significantly more anterior movement compared to the unaffected knee (because the affected knee started from a posteriorly displaced position) and may be mistaken for a positive anterior drawer test. The result of this mistake is a misdiagnosis of ACL injury when, in fact, it is the PCL that is injured!

D) INCORRECT:

Medial collateral ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. MCL injury frequently occurs after valgus stress and presents with medial joint line tenderness and valgus stress laxity.

E) INCORRECT:

Lateral collateral ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain the patient's positive posterior drawer test. Isolated LCL injury is rare; it would present with lateral joint line tenderness with varus stress laxity.

F) INCORRECT:

Lateral meniscus injury causes knee pain but would not explain this patient's positive posterior drawer test. Instead, McMurray test would be positive.
questions.hint: Flexion of the quadriceps of the right thigh would translate the tibia forward; this is called a positive quadriceps active test and it is another sign of the patient's condition.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Four days ago, he injured his right knee while playing soccer. Increased laxity of the right knee joint is noted when the knee is flexed to 30° and an abducting force is applied to the lower leg. The examination finding in this patient is most likely caused by damage to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A posterior cruciate ligament tear would cause increased joint laxity when the knee is flexed and a posterior translating force is applied to the lower leg (posterior drawer sign), unlike the findings in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A tear in the medial meniscus would cause knee pain when the knee is flexed and the lower leg is externally rotated, unlike the findings in this patient.

The medial meniscus is often injured along with the structure that is injured in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A tear in the lateral collateral ligament would cause increased joint laxity when the knee is flexed and an adducting force is applied to the lower leg (varus stress test), unlike the findings in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

A tear in the lateral meniscus would cause knee pain when the knee is flexed and the lower leg is internally rotated, unlike the findings in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Injury to the medial collateral ligament would cause increased laxity of the knee joint when the knee is flexed and an abducting force is applied to the lower leg (valgus stress test). Medial collateral ligament injury is often associated with injury to the anterior cruciate ligament and medial meniscus (unhappy triad).

F) INCORRECT:

An anterior cruciate ligament tear would cause increased joint laxity when the knee is flexed and an anterior translating force is applied to the lower leg (anterior drawer sign and Lachman sign), unlike the findings in this patient.

The anterior cruciate ligament is often injured along with the structure that is injured in this patient.
questions.hint: The patient's injury is likely to be one of the injuries that comprise the unhappy triad.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department immediately after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. On arrival, she says she has severe pain in her left knee and is unable to walk. She is otherwise healthy. Her mother has osteoporosis. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 132/94 mm Hg. Physical examination of the left knee shows significant swelling and ecchymosis with intact skin. The head of the left tibia is anterior to the femoral condyles. Neurovascular examination shows a diminished left dorsal pedal pulse. In addition to analgesia, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Tibiofemoral dislocations are potentially limb-threatening injuries, as they are often associated with neurovascular injury. Reduction should not be delayed for further diagnostics, especially if vascular compromise is suspected (e.g., diminished distal pulses). Vascular compromise can result from compression by displaced surrounding structures and may be reversible with reduction. Immediate closed reduction should be performed to treat anterior tibiofemoral dislocations. Following reduction, pulses are reevaluated and ankle-brachial index is measured to screen for vascular injury. If vascular injury is suspected, further imaging with either doppler ultrasonography or CT angiography may be performed. X-rays of the knee can confirm reduction.

For cases of posterolateral tibiofemoral dislocation, in which the medial collateral ligament and medial capsule invaginate into the joint, open reduction is indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Open reduction and fixation are indicated for a posterolateral tibiofemoral dislocation. Although posterolateral dislocations result from high-energy trauma and manifest with pain, swelling, and inability to bear weight, this patient's tibia is palpated anterior to the femoral condyles, which suggests an anterior rather than posterior tibiofemoral dislocation. An indentation of the skin at the medial femoral condyle can also be seen in patients with posterolateral dislocations as a result of the invagination of soft tissue into the intercondylar notch.

C) INCORRECT:

X-rays of the knee can be used in the evaluation of patients with suspected knee dislocation. However, if the mechanism of injury (e.g., high-velocity trauma) and physical examination findings (visible and palpable displacement of the tibia) are highly suspicious for tibiofemoral dislocation, immediate treatment should not be delayed to obtain imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Ankle-brachial index (ABI) should be measured in patients with tibiofemoral dislocation to screen for vascular injury. An ABI > 0.9 is considered normal, and an ABI < 0.9 should prompt further vascular evaluation. However, as signs of vascular compromise can result from compression by surrounding displaced structures, they might be reversible prior to starting management. Therefore, ABI is typically only measured after initial treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

CT angiography should be performed in patients with tibiofemoral dislocation and suspected vascular injury. Although this patient has a diminished left dorsal pedal pulse, this finding might be reversible, as it can result from compression by the surrounding displaced structures. Therefore, immediate treatment is appropriate before any further vascular evaluation. CT angiography is indicated if the signs of suspected vascular injury persist after treatment.
questions.hint: Displacement of the tibia anterior to the femoral condyles and knee instability following a high-energy trauma is suggestive of anterior tibiofemoral dislocation.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old male college student reports a one-week history of left knee pain and instability. He had been tackled from the left side during a football game and immediately felt a pop. His left knee began to swell, and he had trouble walking. The swelling improved after 1 to 2 days, making walking possible, albeit with some discomfort. The patient reports that his left knee is now very unstable, giving out frequently.
On examination of the joints, the patient’s left knee is swollen and warm with a moderate effusion. There is limited range of motion, with full extension and flexion to approximately 100 degrees (the contralateral leg has 140 degrees of flexion). The left tibia transitions anteriorly when the knee is flexed 90 degrees and anterior force is applied to the tibia; this does not occur on the right. The Lachman test is positive for the left knee but negative for the right knee.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s knee pain?

choices.text: Tear of the medial collateral ligament
Tear of the posterior cruciate ligament
Tear of the lateral collateral ligament
Tear of the anterior cruciate ligament

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with a meniscal tear may have a positive McMurray test, characterized by a painful click as the knee is extended from a fully flexed position and the tibia is externally or internally rotated.

B) INCORRECT:

A tear in the medial collateral ligament occurs after a laterally directed force to the knee, and can also be seen with a significant twisting injury. The patient may have a positive valgus stress test.

C) INCORRECT:

A tear in the posterior cruciate ligament occurs less frequently than a tear to the anterior cruciate ligament. The mechanism of injury is usually an anterior-to-posterior force applied to the lower leg. A positive posterior drawer test result is evident when the examiner flexes the knee to 90 degrees and applies a posterior force to the tibial tubercle and posterior displacement occurs. The examiner may also note a positive posterior-sag test or drop back of the tibial tubercle during the test.

D) INCORRECT:

A tear of the lateral collateral ligament often manifests with a positive varus stress test. Patients with a presumed isolated lateral collateral ligament injury should still be examined for a posterior cruciate ligament or posterolateral corner injury.

E) CORRECT:

A lateral contact injury to the knee that is followed by signs and symptoms of a joint effusion and functional instability is most indicative of an isolated anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury. Typically, the patient notes a popping sound, followed immediately by swelling of the knee due to hemarthrosis.

Functional instability of the knee is ascertained by stress testing. The anterior drawer sign, the Lachman test, and the pivot shift test, if positive, increase the likelihood of an ACL injury.

• Although the anterior drawer sign, performed with the hip flexed 45 degrees and the knee flexed 90 degrees, is not very sensitive, a displacement of greater than 6 mm of the tibia from the femur compared with the opposite normal knee indicates an injury to the ACL.
• The Lachman test, performed with the knee flexed between 15 and 30 degrees, is considered positive if an anterior force displaces the tibia forward more than 5 mm compared with the opposite side.
• The pivot shift test, which can be painful for the patient, is performed with the knee in full extension with application of a valgus and internal rotation stress through ankle rotation.

The history, physical examination, and plain-knee radiographs help establish a provisional diagnosis but may be misleading in cases of more than one ligamentous injury. MRI imaging can be used to confirm an unclear diagnosis, to determine the extent of damage, and to guide decision-making regarding surgical intervention.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of acute knee pain after lateral contact injury, with a positive Lachman test and a positive anterior drawer test, is a tear of the anterior cruciate ligament.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman presents with left knee pain 2 weeks after being an unrestrained passenger in a vehicle that was rear-ended. Upon impact, she slid forward and hit her left knee on the dashboard. Since the injury, she has had mild pain in the back of the knee, persistent swelling, and pain with deep squatting. She denies any prior injury to the knee.
She walks with a slight limp. There is a small joint effusion but no points of focal tenderness. The left knee lacks about 15 degrees of flexion, compared with the unaffected knee.
Muscle-strength testing is normal with resisted knee flexion and extension. With the knee flexed to 90 degrees, the foot in neutral position, and a posterior force applied to the proximal tibia (posterior drawer test), the left leg exhibits greater posterior tibial displacement than the right leg. In that same position, the tibia appears to be flush with the femoral condyles (posterior sag sign). Anterior drawer, Lachman, varus stress, valgus stress, and McMurray tests are all negative.
Neurovascular examination is normal.
Given this patient’s examination findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The posterior drawer test and the posterior sag sign are used to detect injury to the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL). Motor vehicle crashes are a common cause of PCL injuries. A dashboard injury occurs with the knee in a flexed position as a posterior-directed force is applied to the tibia. In athletes, the mechanism of a PCL injury is most often a fall on the flexed knee with a plantar flexed foot and hyperflexion of the knee. The PCL can also be torn by a hyperextension mechanism.

Most patients with a PCL injury report vague, nonspecific symptoms. In the acute setting, patients may complain of knee effusion, stiffness, mild-to-moderate pain in the posterior aspect of the knee, and pain with deep flexion. Patients rarely report having felt a pop at the time of injury or instability with activity. There may be a 10- to 20-degree difference in knee flexion between the affected and the unaffected side, as well as mild effusion upon manual palpation.

To assess the integrity of the PCL, the posterior drawer test is the most accurate (90% sensitivity and 99% specificity). The test is performed with the subject supine, the hip of the affected leg flexed to 45 degrees, the knee flexed to 90 degrees, and the foot in a neutral position. While sitting on the foot of the patient’s affected leg, wrap both hands around the patient’s proximal tibia with your thumbs in the region of the tibial tuberosity. Then apply a posterior force to the proximal tibia. Greater posterior tibial displacement in the affected (compared with the unaffected) lower extremity suggests a partial or a complete PCL tear.

The posterior sag sign, also known as the step-off sign, is 79% sensitive and 100% specific for a PCL injury. This test uses the same starting position as the posterior drawer test. If the PCL is intact, the medial tibial plateau lies at least 1 cm anterior to the femoral condyle when viewed directly from the side. If this anterior positioning is diminished or lost, the posterior sag sign is considered positive. In a grade I PCL injury, the tibia continues to lie anterior to the femoral condyles, but the difference is slightly diminished (0- to 5-mm joint laxity). In a grade II injury, the tibia is flush with the femoral condyles (5- to 10-mm joint laxity). In a grade III injury, the tibia lies posterior to the femoral condyles (>10-mm joint laxity).

Key learning point: A positive posterior drawer test and posterior sag sign are indicative of injury to the posterior cruciate ligament.

B) INCORRECT:

With negative varus and valgus stress testing, injury to the lateral (fibular) or medial collateral ligaments is unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

With negative varus and valgus stress testing, injury to the lateral (fibular) or medial collateral ligaments is unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

With normal strength testing on knee extension, patellar tendon rupture is unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

With a negative anterior drawer test and Lachman test, injury to the anterior cruciate ligament is unlikely.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman presents with right-knee pain that began during a soccer game yesterday. She reports that she was planting her foot to kick the ball when she felt a pop, and her knee buckled. She was unable to continue playing and had to be carried off the field. The joint became swollen about 30 minutes after the injury. Since then, she has been able to bear some weight on the right leg but says that her knee does not feel stable.
Which one of the following test results is most likely in this case?

choices.text: With the patient lying supine and the knee flexed to 90 degrees, a posterior force is applied to the tibia, and the tibia is felt to slide backward without a firm end point

With the patient lying supine and the knee flexed to 25 degrees, the tibia is moved left and right (varus and valgus), and there is more laxity (opening) with the tibia directed valgus on the injured side

With the patient lying supine and the knee flexed to 90 degrees, varus pressure is applied to the knee while the foot is rotated internally and the knee is simultaneously extended; there is a palpable click along the medial joint line, and the patient feels pain at that spot in the knee
With the patient lying prone and the knee flexed to 90 degrees, downward pressure is applied to the tibia while the foot is rotated internally and externally, eliciting pain

With the patient lying supine and the knee flexed to 30 degrees, an anterior force is applied to the tibia while the femur is stabilized, and the tibia is felt to slide forward without a firm end point

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The posterior drawer test is performed in a similar manner to the anterior drawer test, but the tibia is pushed posteriorly. A lack of a firm end point is most consistent with an injury to the posterior cruciate ligament, which is unlikely in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Injury of the medial collateral ligament (MCL) can be assessed by applying valgus stress to the knee (pushing the tibia laterally at the foot while applying medial pressure to the outer knee) with the knee flexed to 25 degrees; if there is increased laxity, the test is considered positive for MCL injury. The lateral collateral ligament (LCL) is examined in a similar manner except that varus stress is applied to the tibia (pushing the tibia medially while applying lateral pressure to the inner knee). This patient’s mechanism of injury is unlikely to have caused damage to the MCL or LCL

C) INCORRECT:

Meniscal injury can be assessed with a number of maneuvers, including the McMurray test. During the McMurray test, the patient is supine, and one hand is placed on the knee, with the fingers and thumb on the medial and lateral joint lines. The other hand lifts the patient’s heel and flexes and extends the knee back and forth several times, first with the tibia rotated externally and valgus stress applied to the knee (to test the medial meniscus) — and then with the tibia rotated internally and varus stress applied (to test the lateral meniscus). A positive test is defined as clicking, catching, or popping at the joint line during early or mid-extension of the knee and indicates a meniscal tear.

D) INCORRECT:

Meniscal injury can be assessed with a number of maneuvers, including the grind (or Apley compression) test. During the grind (or Apley compression) test, the patient lies prone, and the knee is flexed to 90 degrees. While stabilizing the femur, the examiner grasps the foot and applies downward pressure on the tibia while rotating the foot internally and then externally. Pain on compression indicates a meniscal tear. In this case, a meniscal tear is less likely than an ACL injury.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is most consistent with injury to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). The typical mechanism for a noncontact ACL injury is running or jumping followed by suddenly decelerating and changing direction, or pivoting in a way that involves rotation or lateral bending of the knee. Contact-related ACL injuries usually occur when a direct blow causes hyperextension or valgus stress to the knee. The patient typically describes a pop at the knee at the time of injury, acute swelling, and a feeling of knee instability (“my knee gives out”).

If the ACL is damaged, the Lachman test is likely to be positive on physical examination. This test is performed with the patient supine, relaxing the hamstrings. The examiner passively flexes the knee to 30 degrees and pulls the proximal tibia anteriorly while stabilizing the femur distally, attempting to produce anterior translation of the tibia. Greater translation (compared with the uninjured knee) and a soft end point suggest an ACL injury. The Lachman test has a sensitivity of 85% and a specificity of 94% for ACL rupture.

Another test for ACL injury is the anterior drawer test, performed with the patient supine and with the knee flexed to 90 degrees with the foot resting on the examination table and stabilized by the examiner sitting on the end of the foot. The proximal tibia is gripped with both hands and pulled anteriorly; anterior translation with lack of a firm end point constitutes a positive test. The anterior drawer test has a sensitivity of 92% and a specificity of 91% for chronic ACL rupture but is not as accurate in acute injury.

Key learning point: The Lachman test can be used to diagnose an injury to the anterior cruciate ligament.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old female soccer player presents to discuss strategies to prevent reinjury of her anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). Six months ago, she sustained a noncontact, right ACL tear during a game and underwent successful reconstruction of the ligament using an ipsilateral hamstring tendon autograft. She has been increasing her physical activity since then but is concerned about reinjury.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate to minimize this patient’s risk for reinjury?

choices.text: Avoidance of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug therapy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Several factors influence the likelihood of anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury in young female athletes. ACL circumference and joint laxity are thought to play a role, as are several modifiable neuromuscular factors, including knee valgus position, quadriceps and hamstrings muscular activation, and trunk control during dynamic activity.

Neuromuscular training, an intense physical and mental conditioning process, is designed to increase both the strength of the knee joint and the athlete’s awareness of proper balance and technique. Neuromuscular training that focuses on these factors has been shown to significantly reduce the risk for ACL reinjury.

Key learning point: The most effective rehabilitation approach to prevent reinjury after surgical reconstruction of the anterior cruciate ligament in an athlete is neuromuscular training.

B) INCORRECT:

Permanent cessation of organized sports is not an appropriate recommendation for this patient. With appropriate neuromuscular training, she can resume organized sports. However, she should not return to athletics until she has undergone appropriate training; return to athletics in less than 6 months is associated with increased risks for both ACL graft injury and contralateral ACL injury.

C) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy modalities, including therapeutic ultrasound and electrical stimulation, do not reduce the risk for ACL reinjury.

D) INCORRECT:

Preferential loss of strength in the quadriceps and, to a lesser extent, the hamstrings appears to occur after an ACL injury. It is important for the recovering patient to do strengthening exercises for both the hamstrings and the quadriceps muscle groups (in an appropriate ratio) and to emphasize overall neuromuscular control.

E) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy modalities, including therapeutic ultrasound and electrical stimulation, do not reduce the risk for ACL reinjury, nor would avoiding use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl presents with right-knee pain that began during a soccer game yesterday. She reports that she was planting her foot to kick the ball when she felt a pop, and her knee buckled. She was unable to continue playing and had to be carried off the field. The joint became swollen about 30 minutes after the injury. Since then, she has been able to bear some weight on the right leg but says that her knee does not feel stable.
Which one of the following test results is most likely in this case?

choices.text: With the patient lying supine and the knee flexed to 25 degrees, the tibia is moved left and right (varus and valgus), and there is more laxity (opening) with the tibia directed valgus on the injured side

With the patient lying supine and the knee flexed to 30 degrees, an anterior force is applied to the tibia while the femur is stabilized, and the tibia is felt to slide forward without a firm end point
With the patient lying prone and the knee flexed to 90 degrees, downward pressure is applied to the tibia while the foot is rotated internally and externally, eliciting pain

With the patient lying supine and the knee flexed to 90 degrees, varus pressure is applied to the knee while the foot is rotated internally and the knee is simultaneously extended; there is a palpable click along the medial joint line, and the patient feels pain at that spot in the knee
With the patient lying supine and the knee flexed to 90 degrees, a posterior force is applied to the tibia, and the tibia is felt to slide backward without a firm end point

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Injury of the medial collateral ligament (MCL) can be assessed by applying valgus stress to the knee (pushing the tibia laterally at the foot while applying medial pressure to the outer knee) with the knee flexed to 25 degrees; if there is increased laxity, the test is considered positive for MCL injury. The lateral collateral ligament (LCL) is examined in a similar manner except that varus stress is applied to the tibia (pushing the tibia medially while applying lateral pressure to the inner knee). This patient’s mechanism of injury is unlikely to have caused damage to the MCL or LCL.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is most consistent with injury to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). The typical mechanism for a noncontact ACL injury is running or jumping followed by suddenly decelerating and changing direction, or pivoting in a way that involves rotation or lateral bending of the knee. Contact-related ACL injuries usually occur when a direct blow causes hyperextension or valgus stress to the knee. The patient typically describes a pop at the knee at the time of injury, acute swelling, and a feeling of knee instability (“my knee gives out”).

Evaluation for ACL Injury:

If the ACL is damaged, the Lachman test is likely to be positive on physical examination. As shown below, this test is performed with the patient supine, relaxing the hamstrings. The examiner passively flexes the knee to 30 degrees and pulls the proximal tibia anteriorly while stabilizing the femur distally, attempting to produce anterior translation of the tibia. Greater translation (compared with the uninjured knee) and a soft end point suggest an ACL injury. The Lachman test has a sensitivity of 85% and a specificity of 94% for ACL rupture.

Another test for ACL injury is the anterior drawer test, performed with the patient supine and with the knee flexed to 90 degrees with the foot resting on the examination table and stabilized by the examiner sitting on the end of the foot. The proximal tibia is gripped with both hands and pulled anteriorly; anterior translation with lack of a firm end point constitutes a positive test. The anterior drawer test has a sensitivity of 92% and a specificity of 91% for chronic ACL rupture but is not as accurate in acute injury.

Key learning point: The Lachman test can be used to diagnose an injury to the anterior cruciate ligament.

C) INCORRECT:

During the grind (or Apley compression) test, the patient lies prone, and the knee is flexed to 90 degrees. While stabilizing the femur, the examiner grasps the foot and applies downward pressure on the tibia while rotating the foot internally and then externally. Pain on compression indicates a meniscal tear. In this case, a meniscal tear is less likely than an ACL injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Meniscal injury can be assessed with a number of maneuvers, including the McMurray test and the grind (or Apley compression) test. During the McMurray test, the patient is supine, and one hand is placed on the knee, with the fingers and thumb on the medial and lateral joint lines. The other hand lifts the patient’s heel and flexes and extends the knee back and forth several times, first with the tibia rotated externally and valgus stress applied to the knee (to test the medial meniscus) — and then with the tibia rotated internally and varus stress applied (to test the lateral meniscus). A positive test is defined as clicking, catching, or popping at the joint line during early or mid-extension of the knee and indicates a meniscal tear.

E) INCORRECT:

The posterior drawer test is performed in a similar manner to the anterior drawer test, but the tibia is pushed posteriorly. A lack of a firm end point is most consistent with an injury to the posterior cruciate ligament, which is unlikely in this case.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents for evaluation 2 days after sustaining a knee injury while playing soccer with his high-school team. He says that he had planted his left leg while attempting to strike the ball with his right foot when he felt a pop in his left knee. He initially had severe pain in his left knee but says it has improved; however, he now has significant swelling in the knee despite applying ice and a compression wrap. He is able to bear weight but has the sensation that his left knee will give out at any moment. Both he and his parents are concerned because he has multiple college scholarships for soccer to consider.
An initial radiograph of the left knee shows a small, minimally displaced avulsion of the lateral tibial plateau.
In addition to starting this patient on nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, what is the best next step in evaluating or managing the most likely cause of his injury?

choices.text: Compression sleeve and immediate referral to physical therapy
Glucocorticoid injection into the affected knee
Referral for long leg cast for 6 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is the study of choice when there is concern for knee dislocation and vascular injury to the popliteal artery. Patients with knee dislocation often have obvious anterior or posterior translation deformity on physical examination, which is not described in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy is an important part of recovery after ACL reconstruction. In addition, it can help patients to regain motion and reduce swelling after the initial injury and before any surgical procedure. However, patients should still undergo surgical evaluation first so that a proper diagnosis and treatment plan can be delivered to both the patient and therapist.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid injections are not indicated for the treatment of acute ACL injury. They can be used for inflammatory arthropathy or arthritis, neither of which is likely in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s injury pattern is highly concerning for anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) rupture. A planted lower extremity with a twisting motion places great force on the stabilizing ligaments of the knee. A careful examination with particular attention to ligamentous testing is key for diagnosis.

Recognizing the lateral tibial avulsion (or Segond) fracture on radiographs is another important indicator of ACL rupture. Plain film reveals a bony fragment that has avulsed from the tibial plateau.

Although this fracture fragment is not the attachment site of the ACL, it is almost pathognomonic for ACL rupture. A significant force is required to cause lateral capsular ligaments to avulse at their attachment site on the proximal tibia.

Initial management should be supportive, with a hinged knee brace and orthopedic referral. MRI is also indicated to assess the structural components of the knee. Competitive athletes often opt for surgical repair of ACL injuries; however, the lateral tibial avulsion itself does not usually require surgical repair.

Key learning point: When a knee radiograph shows an avulsion of the lateral tibial plateau, it is important to suspect an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient’s small avulsion fracture does not require casting and should heal well without immobilization. Instead, attention should be directed at the underlying ACL injury for functional improvement.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the office because of pain and swelling in his right knee that began 3 days ago when he fell during football practice. He fell on his flexed right knee as he dove to complete a pass. He felt some mild knee pain but continued to practice. Over the next 2 days, the pain worsened and the knee began to swell. Today, the patient has an antalgic gait. Examination shows a swollen and tender right knee; flexion is limited by pain. The right knee is flexed and pressure is applied to proximal tibia; 8 mm of backward translation of the foreleg is observed. Which of the following is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medial meniscus injury is a common cause of knee pain but would not explain this patient's positive posterior drawer test. Instead, McMurray test would be positive.

B) CORRECT:

Posterior cruciate ligament injury (PCL injury) can occur when the flexed knee is subjected to excessive posterior force, as in the case of this patient. He has a positive posterior drawer sign on the affected side, which is highly suggestive of PCL injury. PCL injury is confirmed by MRI and can be treated conservatively (in the case of isolated injury) or surgically (in the case of multi-ligament injury or chronic symptoms).
Image Description:

MRI knee (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) appears thickened and heterogeneous with an irregular and ill-defined contour (green overlay). It contains multiple areas of intermediate signal intensity, indicating tearing. A joint effusion is demonstrated by the hyperintense signal in the suprapatellar pouch (red overlay).

A ligament tear does not always appear as a discrete defect and may be demonstrated by the features in this example. A normal PCL should appear as hypointense on all conventional MRI sequences and have smooth margins.

C) INCORRECT:

Anterior cruciate ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. Instead, ACL injury would present with a positive anterior drawer sign and a positive Lachman sign.

D) INCORRECT:

Medial collateral ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. MCL injury frequently occurs after valgus stress and presents with medial joint line tenderness and valgus stress laxity.

E) INCORRECT:

Lateral collateral ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain the patient's positive posterior drawer test. Isolated LCL injury is rare; it would present with lateral joint line tenderness with varus stress laxity.
questions.hint: Flexion of the quadriceps of the right thigh would translate the tibia forward; this is called a positive quadriceps active test and it is another sign of the patient's condition.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her coach 30 minutes after injuring her left knee while playing field hockey. She was tackled from the left side and has been unable to bear weight on her left leg since the accident. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The medial joint line is tender to touch. The patient's hip is slightly flexed and abducted, and the knee is slightly flexed while the patient is in the supine position. Gentle valgus stress is applied across the left knee and medial joint laxity is noted. The remainder of the examination shows no further abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with posterior cruciate ligament injury often present with knee swelling. However, physical examination usually shows posterior knee instability rather than medial instability, and affected individuals usually experience minimal or no pain. In addition, injury caused by lateral direct force to the knee is an uncommon cause of posterior cruciate ligament injury, which is most commonly caused by noncontact injuries involving hyperflexion of the knee with a plantarflexed foot or contact injuries with force applied from the posterior side of the knee.
Image Description:

MRI knee (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) appears thickened and heterogeneous with an irregular and ill-defined contour (green overlay). It contains multiple areas of intermediate signal intensity, indicating tearing. A joint effusion is demonstrated by the hyperintense signal in the suprapatellar pouch (red overlay).

A ligament tear does not always appear as a discrete defect and may be demonstrated by the features in this example. A normal PCL should appear as hypointense on all conventional MRI sequences and have smooth margins.

B) INCORRECT:

Knee swelling and medial knee pain may be caused by medial meniscus injury. However, meniscus tears do not usually cause knee instability. Moreover, a lesion of the medial meniscus would typically lead to pain during adduction of the knee (varus stress), not during abduction (valgus stress), making the diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

MRI knee (upper image: T1-weighted, coronal plane; lower image: T1-weighted, sagittal plane)

There is horizontal linear intermediate signal (white outline), parallel to the tibial plateau, within the posterior horn of the medial meniscus (green overlay).

This is consistent with a horizontal meniscal tear.

Red overlay: anterior horn of the medial meniscus

C) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury include knee swelling, pain, and instability after an inciting trauma. However, ACL injury most frequently occurs in the setting of noncontact sports injuries with a twisting mechanism, not a direct blow to the knee. In addition, valgus stress test would show anterior knee instability, not medial knee instability.
Image Description:

MRI knee (STIR; sagittal view)

The anterior cruciate ligament is discontinuous. The distal part of the ligament demonstrates normal hypointense signal (red overlay), but the proximal half ligament demonstrates heterogenous hyperintense signal (yellow overlay). There is a gap between these two areas. There is also a large suprapatellar joint effusion (demonstrated as a white area due to high signal intensity; blue overlay). The partially imaged posterior cruciate ligament (green overlay) appears intact.

This is an example of an anterior cruciate ligament rupture. The gap between the proximal and distal half of the ligament indicates it is a full-thickness tear. The heterogeneous hyperintense signal of the proximal half indicates partial thickness tearing of that component.

D) INCORRECT:

Lateral collateral ligament (LCL) injury typically manifests with knee swelling, pain, and instability. However, affected individuals typically have a positive varus stress test, not a positive valgus stress test. LCL injury is typically caused by varus stress with possible external rotation, not a lateral force to the knee (valgus stress).

E) CORRECT:

This patient has the characteristic features of medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury, including medial joint line tenderness and medial joint laxity, as confirmed by a positive valgus stress test. Knee swelling and pain are also commonly seen in this condition. Contact injury involving valgus stress on the knee, such as a tackle from the side, is the mechanism that most commonly causes MCL injury.

MCL injury is frequently associated with a medial meniscus tear, which can be assessed on physical exam. In this case, the remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities, which makes a concurrent meniscus injury less likely.
Image Description:

A triad of medial meniscus, anterior cruciate ligament, and medial collateral ligament tears. This injury typically occurs due to excessive valgus and external rotational stress with a fixed foot position.
questions.hint: The patient's injury is likely to be one of the injuries that comprise the unhappy triad.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male college student reports a one-week history of left knee pain and instability. He had been tackled from the left side during a football game and immediately felt a pop. His left knee began to swell, and he had trouble walking. The swelling improved after 2 days, making walking possible, albeit with some discomfort. The patient reports that his left knee is now very unstable, giving out frequently. On examination of the joints, the patient’s left knee is swollen and warm with a moderate effusion. There is limited range of motion, with full extension and flexion to approximately 100 degrees (the contralateral leg has 140 degrees of flexion). The left tibia transitions anteriorly when the knee is flexed 90 degrees and anterior force is applied to the tibia; this does not occur on the right. The Lachman test is positive for the left knee but negative for the right knee. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s knee pain?

choices.text: Tear of the medial collateral ligament
Tear of the posterior cruciate ligament
Tear of the lateral collateral ligament
Tear of the anterior cruciate ligament

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with a meniscal tear may have a positive McMurray test, characterized by a painful click as the knee is extended from a fully flexed position and the tibia is externally or internally rotated.

B) INCORRECT:

A tear in the medial collateral ligament occurs after a laterally directed force to the knee, and can also be seen with a significant twisting injury. The patient may have a positive valgus stress test.

C) INCORRECT:

A tear in the posterior cruciate ligament occurs less frequently than a tear to the anterior cruciate ligament. The mechanism of injury is usually an anterior-to-posterior force applied to the lower leg. A positive posterior drawer test result is evident when the examiner flexes the knee to 90 degrees and applies a posterior force to the tibial tubercle and posterior displacement occurs. The examiner may also note a positive posterior-sag test or drop back of the tibial tubercle during the test.

D) INCORRECT:

A tear of the lateral collateral ligament often manifests with a positive varus stress test. Patients with a presumed isolated lateral collateral ligament injury should still be examined for a posterior cruciate ligament or posterolateral corner injury.

E) CORRECT:

A lateral contact injury to the knee that is followed by signs and symptoms of a joint effusion and functional instability is most indicative of an isolated anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury. Typically, the patient notes a popping sound, followed immediately by swelling of the knee due to hemarthrosis. Functional instability of the knee is ascertained by stress testing.

The history, physical examination, and plain-knee radiographs help establish a provisional diagnosis but may be misleading in cases of more than one ligamentous injury. MRI imaging can be used to confirm an unclear diagnosis, to determine the extent of damage, and to guide decision-making regarding surgical intervention.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of acute knee pain after lateral contact injury, with a positive Lachman test and a positive anterior drawer test, is a tear of the anterior cruciate ligament.
questions.hint: This patient has a positive anterior drawer test, a positive Lachman test, and a positive pivot shift test, all of which increase the likelihood of this type of injury.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old collegiate soccer player presents with right knee pain and swelling after feeling a sudden 'pop' while pivoting during a match. She was unable to continue playing. On examination, the knee is swollen and tender. With the knee flexed at 90°, there is marked forward translation of the tibia relative to the femur compared to the uninjured leg. There is no tenderness over the medial joint line or instability with valgus stress.
Which structure is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The medial collateral ligament (MCL) resists valgus stress. MCL injuries typically present with medial knee pain, tenderness, and valgus instability. The absence of medial joint tenderness and valgus instability, along with anterior tibial translation, indicates a different injury, not an MCL tear.

B) INCORRECT:

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) prevents posterior translation of the tibia. An injury would result in excessive posterior tibial movement, assessed by the posterior drawer test or sag sign. The clinical findings of anterior tibial translation and the mechanism of injury suggest an ACL, not PCL, injury.

C) CORRECT:

The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) prevents anterior translation and controls rotational stability of the tibia relative to the femur. A sudden 'pop' during pivoting, followed by rapid knee swelling, is characteristic of an ACL injury. The marked anterior translation of the tibia on examination, particularly with the Lachman test, indicates ACL compromise. Such injuries are common in sports requiring abrupt directional changes. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is essential for confirming the injury and planning management.

Key learning point: An abnormal forward movement of the tibia on the femur, known as the anterior drawer sign, is indicative of an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury.
Image Description:

The patient is in supine position, the leg to be examined is erect, and the knee is flexed at approximately 90°. The examiner puts both hands around the lower leg (with the thumbs placed on the tibial tuberosity). To examine the anterior cruciate ligament, the tibia is pulled ventrally. To examine the posterior cruciate ligament, the tibia is pushed dorsally. If the movability of the tibia is increased (particularly compared to the other leg) or if there is a lax endpoint, the drawer test is said to be positive and may indicate an injury to the respective ligament.

D) INCORRECT:

Medial meniscus injuries often present with medial joint line tenderness and mechanical symptoms like locking or clicking. The absence of medial joint line tenderness and the presence of marked anterior tibial translation suggest a different pathology, inconsistent with an isolated medial meniscus injury.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old soccer player is struck on the lateral side of his right knee while pivoting. He experiences severe medial knee pain, with swelling developing over the next hour. Examination shows tenderness along the medial aspect of the knee and pain with valgus stress testing at 25° of knee flexion. Slight medial joint space opening is noted, but there is no significant anterior or posterior instability.
Which structure is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pes anserine bursitis is typically due to chronic overuse or degenerative conditions, not acute trauma. The described lateral impact with medial pain, swelling, and positive valgus stress test suggests stress on medial stabilizing structures. Pes anserine bursitis does not cause joint instability or medial joint space opening, making it unlikely in this scenario.

B) INCORRECT:

The lateral collateral ligament (LCL) resists varus forces. Injury to the LCL would present with lateral pain and instability during varus stress testing. The described mechanism involves a lateral impact causing valgus stress, leading to medial knee pain and tenderness, indicating medial structure involvement rather than LCL injury.

C) CORRECT:

The medial collateral ligament (MCL) stabilizes the knee against valgus stress. It originates from the medial femoral epicondyle and inserts onto the tibia. A lateral force to the knee, as described, induces valgus stress, leading to medial knee pain and tenderness. Examination reveals pain with valgus stress testing at 25° of knee flexion and slight medial joint space opening, indicating MCL involvement. The absence of significant anterior or posterior instability suggests an isolated MCL injury.

Key learning point: A valgus force to the knee often results in a medial collateral ligament sprain, characterized by medial knee swelling and laxity on valgus stress testing.

D) INCORRECT:

The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is often injured during abrupt deceleration or pivoting, leading to joint effusion and instability. However, the described lateral blow to the knee suggests a valgus force, affecting medial structures. Medial knee tenderness and positive valgus stress testing indicate MCL injury, not ACL involvement. The absence of significant anterior instability further argues against an ACL tear.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of pain and swelling in his right knee that began 3 days ago when he fell during football practice. He fell on his flexed right knee as he dove to complete a pass. He felt some mild knee pain but continued to practice. Over the next 2 days, the pain worsened and the knee began to swell. Osteopathic structural examination reveals:

Antalgic gait favoring the left leg
Swelling and tenderness of the right knee
Limited right knee flexion due to pain
Tender point at the center of the right popliteal fossa
Prominence of the right femoral condyles when the right knee is flexed and pressure is applied to the proximal tibia

Which of the following is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lateral collateral ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain the patient's positive posterior drawer test. Isolated LCL injury is rare; it would present with lateral joint line tenderness with varus stress laxity.

B) INCORRECT:

Medial meniscus injury is a common cause of knee pain but would not explain this patient's positive posterior drawer test. Instead, McMurray test would be positive.

C) INCORRECT:

Medial collateral ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. MCL injury frequently occurs after valgus stress and presents with medial joint line tenderness and valgus stress laxity.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior cruciate ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. Instead, ACL injury would present with a positive anterior drawer sign and a positive Lachman sign.

Patients with PCL injury can sometimes appear to have a positive anterior drawer sign if the examiner is not careful. If a patient has a posterior sag sign from their PCL injury, then the affected tibia is posteriorly displaced when the knee is flexed (as when performing an anterior drawer test). If the examiner is not aware of the posterior sag and performs an anterior drawer test, the affected knee will feel as though it has significantly more anterior movement compared to the unaffected knee (because the affected knee started from a posteriorly displaced position) and may be mistaken for a positive anterior drawer test. The result of this mistake is a misdiagnosis of ACL injury when, in fact, it is the PCL that is injured!

E) CORRECT:

Posterior cruciate ligament injury (PCL injury) can occur when the flexed knee is subjected to excessive posterior force, as in the case of this patient. He has a positive posterior drawer sign on the affected side, which is highly suggestive of PCL injury. PCL injury is confirmed by MRI and can be treated conservatively (in the case of isolated injury) or surgically (in the case of multi-ligament injury or chronic symptoms).
Image Description:

MRI knee (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) appears thickened and heterogeneous with an irregular and ill-defined contour (green overlay). It contains multiple areas of intermediate signal intensity, indicating tearing. A joint effusion is demonstrated by the hyperintense signal in the suprapatellar pouch (red overlay).

A ligament tear does not always appear as a discrete defect and may be demonstrated by the features in this example. A normal PCL should appear as hypointense on all conventional MRI sequences and have smooth margins.
questions.hint: Flexion of the quadriceps of the right thigh would translate the tibia forward; this is called a positive quadriceps active test and it is another sign of the patient's condition.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to your clinic because of pain and swelling in his right knee that began 3 days ago after he fell during football practice. He landed on his flexed right knee while diving to complete a pass. He experienced mild knee pain initially but continued to practice. Over the next 2 days, the pain worsened and swelling developed. Today, he has an antalgic gait. On examination, his right knee is swollen and tender, with flexion limited by pain. When the right knee is flexed and pressure is applied to the proximal tibia, 8 mm of backward translation of the foreleg is observed. Which one of the following structures is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medial meniscus injury is a common cause of knee pain but would not explain this patient's positive posterior drawer test. Instead, McMurray test would be positive.

B) CORRECT:

Posterior cruciate ligament injury (PCL injury) can occur when the flexed knee is subjected to excessive posterior force, as in the case of this patient. He has a positive posterior drawer sign on the affected side, which is highly suggestive of PCL injury. PCL injury is confirmed by MRI and can be treated conservatively (in the case of isolated injury) or surgically (in the case of multi-ligament injury or chronic symptoms).

Key learning point: A positive posterior drawer test after trauma to a flexed knee indicates injury to the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL).
Image Description:

MRI knee (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) appears thickened and heterogeneous with an irregular and ill-defined contour (green overlay). It contains multiple areas of intermediate signal intensity, indicating tearing. A joint effusion is demonstrated by the hyperintense signal in the suprapatellar pouch (red overlay).

A ligament tear does not always appear as a discrete defect and may be demonstrated by the features in this example. A normal PCL should appear as hypointense on all conventional MRI sequences and have smooth margins.

C) INCORRECT:

Anterior cruciate ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. Instead, ACL injury would present with a positive anterior drawer sign and a positive Lachman sign.

D) INCORRECT:

Medial collateral ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. MCL injury frequently occurs after valgus stress and presents with medial joint line tenderness and valgus stress laxity.

E) INCORRECT:

Lateral collateral ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain the patient's positive posterior drawer test. Isolated LCL injury is rare; it would present with lateral joint line tenderness with varus stress laxity.
questions.hint: Flexion of the quadriceps of the right thigh would translate the tibia forward; this is called a positive quadriceps active test and it is another sign of the patient's condition.

questions.text: A 34-year-old construction worker presents after falling from scaffolding, landing with his left knee hyperextended against a concrete beam. On examination, there is obvious deformity with the tibia visibly displaced anteriorly relative to the femur, and the knee is held in slight flexion. The patient has severe pain and is unable to move the knee. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are present but diminished compared to the contralateral side. Sensation is intact distally. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT angiogram of the lower extremity
Urgent orthopedic consultation for open reduction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiogram is indicated for post-reduction evaluation if the ankle-brachial index is less than 0.9 or when vascular injury is suspected, but immediate reduction takes priority to prevent further neurovascular compromise.

B) INCORRECT:

Urgent orthopedic consultation for open reduction is indicated specifically for posterolateral dislocations, but this anterior tibiofemoral dislocation should be managed with immediate closed reduction under procedural sedation.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Immediate closed reduction under procedural sedation is the priority for anterior tibiofemoral dislocation. Reduction should not be delayed to obtain imaging unless an alternate diagnosis is suspected, as immediate reduction prevents neurovascular damage. In cases where orthopedic surgeons are readily available, a bedside X-ray might be reasonable to rapidly rule out fracture/dislocation if it can be obtained without delaying anatomic realignment, as this might affect the reduction approach. In this patient with obvious deformity and evidence of neurovascular compromise, the safest approach is immediate closed reduction followed by post-reduction imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Ankle-brachial index measurement is an important component of the post-reduction neurovascular assessment protocol, but reduction should not be delayed for this evaluation in cases of obvious dislocation.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI is used for evaluation of ligamentous injuries, but does not have a role in the immediate management of tibiofemoral dislocation. Immediate reduction is the priority to prevent limb-threatening neurovascular complications.

questions.text: A 24-year-old soccer player presents to the ED 5 days after a plant and pivot injury to her right knee during a game. She reports hearing a "pop" followed by immediate pain and inability to continue playing. Since the injury, she has experienced episodes of her knee "giving out" when walking. On examination, there is moderate knee effusion and tenderness. With the knee flexed to 20 degrees, anterior displacement of the tibia relative to the femur is noted with a soft endpoint. She is an active, competitive athlete who wants to return to soccer. What is the correct management of the most likely condition?

choices.text: Apply a functional knee brace and refer to physical therapy
Apply an unlocked hinged knee brace and arrange orthopedic follow-up within a week
Apply a knee immobilizer and prescribe strict non-weight-bearing
Consult orthopedic surgery in the ED for immediate repair
Apply ice, prescribe NSAIDs, and arrange sports medicine follow-up in 4–6 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient likely has an ACL tear based on the pivoting mechanism, audible "pop," knee instability, and positive Lachman test. Functional bracing with physical therapy alone would be appropriate for isolated collateral ligament injuries, which typically present with medial or lateral joint line tenderness and positive valgus or varus stress tests rather than anterior tibial displacement. This conservative approach is inadequate for ACL tears in competitive athletes who require surgical reconstruction to return to pivoting sports.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient likely has an ACL tear based on the clinical presentation and positive Lachman test. The priority in the ED is appropriate initial management and timely specialist follow-up for management tailored to this patient's goals. An unlocked hinged knee brace provides stability while allowing controlled movement until she can be evaluated by an orthopedic surgeon. MRI imaging is likely needed to confirm the diagnosis and guide surgical planning; however, it is not always readily available in the ED for this indication. A provisional clinical diagnosis of ACL tear can be made based on reliable physical examination maneuvers, and confirmatory imaging can be obtained as an outpatient. Given this patient's competitive athletic status and desire to return to soccer, she will most likely require arthroscopic ACL reconstruction.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient likely has an ACL tear based on the mechanism and examination findings. Knee immobilizers should be avoided in isolated ligamentous injuries as they negatively affect treatment outcomes by decreasing quadriceps strength. This restrictive approach might be considered for certain fractures or immediately post-operative cases, but even then, early mobilization is generally preferred. The combination of immobilization and non-weight-bearing would lead to significant muscle atrophy and poor outcomes.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient likely has an ACL tear based on the clinical presentation. Emergency surgical consultation would be appropriate for conditions requiring immediate intervention, such as patellar tendon rupture (which would present with inability to extend the knee against gravity and a palpable gap in the tendon), open fractures, or neurovascular compromise. Isolated ACL tears do not require emergent surgical intervention and urgent outpatient follow-up is more appropriate than emergency consultation.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient likely has an ACL tear based on the pivoting mechanism and positive Lachman test. This type of conservative management may be appropriate for meniscus injuries, which typically present with joint line tenderness, mechanical symptoms like locking or catching, and a positive McMurray test (pain or clicking with knee flexion and rotation) rather than the dramatic "pop" and anterior tibial displacement seen with ACL tears. However, a delayed follow-up timeline is inappropriate for ACL tears, which require more timely orthopedic evaluation, particularly in competitive athletes.
